displaytitle: Relief of a carpenter at work

titles.title: Relief of a carpenter at work

texts.textentryhtml: The wealth of Byzantium was legendary, and its capital, Constantinople, was at the crossroads of much of the trade of the civilized world. Foreign visitors were dazzled by its enormous walls, magnificent churches, opulent palaces, and bustling markets. A ten-percent toll on all imported goods raised sizable revenues, and for centuries it was Byzantium that furnished the nations of Western Europe with gold coin. The government kept monopolies on goods such as silk, grain, and weapons. Commodities of all lands poured into the capital, from the agricultural produce that was the foundation of wealth in all ancient and medieval societies, to gold, silver, gems, ivory, furs, perfumes, silk, incense, wine, colored marbles, exotic woods, and slaves. The city’s own products were among the most highly prized and sought after throughout the Mediterranean region. The gold rings, crosses, buckles, and pendants in this case and the objects of silver, ivory, and rock crystal offer but a hint of the wealth that flowed through many levels of Byzantine society. A small finial, intricately inlaid with colored enamel in the cloisonné technique, attests to the high level of artistry attained by the capital’s strictly regulated craft guilds, while the ivory relief of a carpenter, the colorful woven panel from a woolen tunic, and the fragment of a marble grave monument, commissioned by the family of a middle-class citizen, speak to the empire’s legendary but everyday affluence and prosperity.
